reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on April 13, 2019
reviews.text: I play most of my games on my PC - I work in IT so building a PC is a trivial task for me - I haven't gotten a prebuilt desktop in decades. I always like to have a controller though - easier to play on the couch, some games are wonky with the keyboard, and it makes emulation easier.For the past few years I have been using a PS4 controller because I already owned one, but it's a hassle to use on Windows. You need to install third party software for Windows to recognize it, its very temperamental, and a chunk of the features don't work properly because you're using said third party software. Getting the PS4 controller connected wirelessly is an ordeal too - again, since you're using third party software the controller never wants to connect. Steam has built in PS4 controller support, but getting that to function wirelessly is an even bigger ordeal than normal. So you're generally stuck using a wire.I decided to order the Xbox one controller because my buddies were raving about it. The difference between the two controllers is like night and day.First thing is, the Xbox controller is more ergonomic. It takes a little while to get use to the button placement, but it ends up feeling better and more natural. The shape of the controller fits your hand better, and the triggers feel much better. I do miss having the touch pad sometimes, but most of the time I'm just happy I'm not hitting it by mistake. The controller feels much higher quality, and it looks nice too.But the biggest improvement was the ease of setup and reliability. All you have to do is plug it in. That's it. No third party software, no finagling with steam, nothing. It just werks™. Even the little Xbox button works - it pulls up a context sensitive menu. Heck, I can even use the controller outside games with no issue.Setting it up over bluetooth was a breeze too - i paired it one time and that was it. It turns out on it's own after a period of inactivity, and turning it back on just means pushing the Xbox button. With the PS4 controller getting it to reconnect each time watching an ordeal because of the software.One thing that excited me was the ability to plug a wired headset into the jack on the controller and still use the controller wirelessly. That meant I could use a wired headset from across the room just for discord or skype, while still having the sound for the game coming from my high end speakers. But there was a snag - you can't do that over Bluetooth. You can only do it plugged in over usb, or if using the Xbox one wireless adapter, which uses a proprietary format. Thankfully, that adapter was less than 20$ so I ordered one.But there is another snag - you either need to be using a headset with the special Xbox one headset adapter built in, or buy the adapter separately. Now this was a bummer - the adapter itself costs around 60$! So I tried plugging in a regular 3.5 headset to see if it would work anyway, but unfortunately it did not.I bought a Microsoft brand Xbox one headset today, and it works great. The quality isn't amazing, but that's the headsets fault and not the controller. I'm just using the headset for discord anyway - the quality doesn't have to be amazing because it's just for chat. It only covers one ear and is lightweight, so I'm perfectly able to hear the sound from the game itself coming from my nice speakers.Overall, this is a fantastic controller. Probably one of the best I've ever had. I highly recommend getting one, but just be aware that getting the headphone jack to function on a PC is more work than it appears and costs money.
reviews.title: Awesome controller for PC, but using built in headset jack is complicated

reviews.text: This controller works perfect with my Xbox One S. But, it's only a matter of time until it too develops drift like the one it replaces. The standard controllers should be recalled by Microsoft for faulty parts.I bought this as a replacement for a controller that developed the dreaded "drift". After I had a working controller back, I purchased a repair kit for the other controller. As soon as I opened the controller, I started to understand the issue. A small green colored piece of plastic fell out - which immediately was recognized as part of one of the analog sticks.The reason for the drift is that the control used breaks due to a parts flaw. The parts flaw is that the analog stick not built to handle downward pressure on the small switch. When it breaks off the stick the controller develops drift. Of course the downward pressure is what you need to make your character run in some games, so this will inevitably break quickly and you'll have a drifty controller.If you are handy with a soldering iron and desoldering pump, you can easily replace the analog stick in 10 to 15-minutes and save yourself quite a bit of money, especially if you buy several of them at a time.I'm not impressed with the build of Microsoft's controller and considering the price, beefing up the analog stick shouldn't even be a thought. The piece that breaks, the analog stick, is exceptionally flimsy and there appears to be no change being made to fix this well known and well document issue caused by under-engineered parts. Shame on Microsoft.

The first game I played was The Witcher, so I clocked a little over 40 hours.Next, I started playing Apex legends and clocked between 15-20 hours. After that I played around 10 hours of COD before my controller decided to break (right analog stick went haywire). Here is my review of the product:Handling:I really enjoy the Xbox controller. It is sleek and has a nice feel to it (But I still enjoy the PS controller over the Xbox controller). The button layout is top notch, but the issue lies within the left and right stick (for me anyways). After playing Apex legends, I started noticing my character would slowly look down and to the right. At first it wasn’t noticeable, but then it became apparent what was going on.Durability:I’m not rough on my controllers. If I drop it, it usually lands on my bed or my lap. But I have noticed after three controllers within a two year span, the right stick seems to break a lot.Price:I’m not the biggest fan of dropping $60.00 on a controller that tears up within a few months of gameplay. Whereas my PS4 controller has lasted a few years. And I contemplated purchasing the Xbox Elite controller, but both of my friends Elite controllers broke within a year.Overall, this is not a product I can recommend to anyone. I’ve heard the old Xbox 360 controllers were amazing, but I feel like Microsoft cheapened out on this product. I am giving this a two star review, because it showed me how amazing my PlayStation really is.Sincerely,A PlayStation Fan Boy

reviews.text: I didn't initially enjoy the Xbox One controller I bought, I shared a similar sentiment to many that the materials felt somewhat cheap and the ergonomics did not match how I felt about the former Xbox 360 controllers I've used in the past.My biggest initial problem with the controller is the feeling that the control sticks were too tall, narrow, and course to the touch, creating this somewhat uncomfortable play experience during probably my first 5-10hrs of using them.They got a LOT more comfortable to use after a little time of getting used to them, and before I knew it - it's become one of my favorite controllers I've had once I got a bit more accustomed to that nature of it's build/design.Overall Feel = 5/10Didn't quite live up to current expectations with $50+ controllers, materials feel plastic-y and feels rough to use at firstButtons/Feedback = 9/10Thankfully, the button feedback and overall control this gives when playing feels fantastic. Some would argue that the R/L triggers on the bottom take a lot of push to register input, but I personally thought it felt fine. Not as fast as some other controllers, like the Switch Pro or something similar, but responsive.Additional Features? 7/10There aren't a lot of bells and whistles here, what you're seeing is what you get. Once I got it setup on my PC the connection times were fast and simple. Hands down the best PC controller experience I've had once I got around a small Windows 10 hiccup. One feature I do really enjoy is the aux output in the bottom of the controller, I have not personally used it yet but being able to plug-in headphones into a controller is very convenient. And, while this may be a controversial choice to some, the controller's AA battery power is something I really like. I don't have to worry about charging the controller every day or two like I would if I was using my Switch controllers, very nice!All in all, I'm happy with this controller. I will be buying a couple "mods" for it improving on the triggers and thumb-sticks, but otherwise I would recognize the controller for use with PC gaming.

I'm sure the warranty is up by now, and even if I was still able to send it back to Microsoft somehow, I'd be without a controller for who knows how long.Obviously, I'm extremely annoyed by this and will probably have to look elsewhere for a controller seeing how I won't be buying this one again. My wallet can't afford to lose 50 dollars every 3 months on a controller that should last me YEARS like the old ones did. They are making these much cheaper than they used to which really was evident by the weight and feel of the thing when I first got it in May.I should also note that I used my controller in a normal fashion and without applying harsh pressure to any buttons or controls in fear that it would break before I got a few years out of it...but then it broke anyway.Please, I know you're thinking how I did when I researched controllers for hours that week, "This guy's review might be a rare case and my controller might not do that if I buy it," but trust me, based on the cheap plastic and bad engineering, it eventually will. And probably SOONER than you'd hope.

reviews.text: The Xbox controller has one of the best button layouts as well as shape among gaming controllers. Nothing seems as comfortable or as responsive as these controllers. The downside however, is that the quality of the build has not improved much and in fact I’m pretty sure they’ve gone down in quality.The plastic has a texture to promote a better grip which has minimal effect. There is no built in battery which you can take it or leave it depending on your preference. You can’t enable steam control for the home button. The vibration functions suck compared to DualShock 4 and even the switch joy cons. You absolutely need the PC dongle if you plan to use it on pc because Bluetooth has connectivity issues. And very fragile, if you are a rager just get a third party controllerThe pros do outweigh the cons... very very low latency. Comfort is at its best. Decent battery life if you shut off vibration which you get used too really quick. Best joysticks and buttons/triggers of any controller I’ve used. Actually works great for mobile games with controller support if your into that.All in all, it’s not perfect but it’s pretty darn close.
